sp.p: Well, if youle saue me harmlesse, and put me vnder couert barne, I am content to please you prouided it may breed no wrong against him.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No wrong at all: here take the Key, be gone:
If any vex him, this: if not this, none Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: O Roger, Roger, where's your mistris, wher's your mistris? there's the finest, neatest Gentleman at my house, but newly come ouer: O where is she, where is she, where is she?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: My mistris is abroad, but not amongst em: my mistris is not the whore now that you take her for.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: How? is she not a whore? do you go about to take away her good name, Roger? you are a fine Pandar indeed.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I tell you, Madona Finger-locke, I am not sad for nothing, I ha not eaten one good meale this three & thirty dayes: I had wont to get sixteene pence by fetching a pottle of Hypocras: but now those dayes are past: we had as good doings, Madona Finger-locke, she within dores and I without, as any poore yong couple in Millain.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Gods my life, and is she chang'd now?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I ha lost by her squeamishnesse, more then would haue builded 12. bawdy houses.

And had she no time to turn honest but now? what a vile woman is this? twenty pound a night, Ile be sworne, Roger, in good gold and no siluer: why here was a time, if she should ha pickt out a time, it could not be better! gold ynough stirring; choyce of men, choyce of haire, choyce of beards, choyce of legs, and choyce of euery, euery, euery thing: it cannot sink into my head, that she should be such an Asse. Roger, I neuer beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Here she comes now. Enter Bellafronte.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: O sweet Madona, on with your loose gowne, your felt & your feather, there's the sweetest, proprest, gallantest Gentleman at my house, he smells all of Muske & Amber greece, his pocket full of Crownes, flame-colourd dublet, red satin hose, Carnation silk stockins, and a leg and a body, oh!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hence, thou our sexes monster, poysonous Bawd,
Lusts Factor, and damnations Orator,
Gossip of hell, were all the Harlots sinnes
Which the whole world conteynes, numbred together,
Thine farre exceeds them all; of all the creatures
That euer were created, thou art basest:
What serpent would beguile thee of thy Office?
It is detestable: for thou liu'st
Vpon the dregs of Harlots, guard'st the dore,
Whilst couples goe to dauncing: O course deuill!
Thou art the bastards curse, thou brandst his birth,
The lechers French disease; for thou dry-suckst him:
The Harlots poyson, and thine owne confusion.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Mary come vp with a pox, haue you no body to raile against, but your Bawd now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And you, Knaue Pandar, kinsman to a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: You and I Madona, are Cozens.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Of the same bloud and making, neere allyed,
Thou, that slaue to sixpence, base-mettald villayne.

sp.speaker: Rog,
sp.p: Sixpence? nay that's not so; I neuer took vnder two shillings foure pence, I hope I know my fee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I know not against which most to inueigh:
For both of you are damnd so equally.
Thou neuer spar'st for oathes: swearst any thing,
As if thy soule were made of shoe-leather.
God dam me, Gentleman, if she be within,
When in the next roome she's found dallying.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: If it be my vocation to sweare, euery man in his vocation: I hope my betters sweare and dam themselues, and why should not I?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Roger, you cheat kind gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: The more gulls they.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Slaue, I casheere thee.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: And you do casheere him, he shalbe entertaynd.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Shall I? then blurt a your seruice.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As hell would haue it, entertaynd by you!
I dare the deuill himselfe to match those two. Exit.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Mary gup, are you growne so holy, so pure, so honest with a pox?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Scuruy honest Punck! But stay Madona, how must our agreement be now? for you know I am to haue all the commings in at the hall dore, & you at the chamber dore.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: True Rog. except my vailes.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Vailes, what vailes?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Why as thus, if a couple come in a Coach, & light to lie down a little, then Roger, thats my fee, & you may walk abroad; for the Coach man himselfe is their Pandar.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Is a so? in truth I haue almost forgot, for want of exercise: But how if I fetch this Citizens wife to that Gull, & that Madona to that Gallant, how then?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Why then, Roger, you are to haue sixpence a lane, so many lanes, so many sixpences.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Ist so? then I see we two shall agree and liue together.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I Roger, so long as there be any Tauernes and bawdy houses in Millain. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENA 9.
div.stage: Enter Bellafronte with a Lute, pen, inke and paper being placde before her.
div.l: That sucke vp poore Bees Honyes:
Silks and Veluets, Pearles and Ambers,
Shall not draw me to their Chambers. Shee writes.
Oh, tis in vayne to write: it will not please,
Inke on this paper would ha but presented
The foule blacke spots that sticke vpon my soule,
And rather make me lothsomer, then wrought
My loues impression in Hipolitoes thought.
No, I must turne the chaste leaues of my brest,
And pick out some sweet meanes to breed my rest.
Hipolito, beleeue me I will be
As true vnto thy heart, as thy heart to thee,
And hate all men, their gifts and company.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You, goody Punck, subandi Cockatrice, O yare a sweet whore of your promise, are you not think you? how wel you came to supper to vs last night: mew, a whore & breake her word! nay you may blush, & hold downe your head at it wel ynough: Sfoot, aske these gallants if we staid not till we were as hungry as Seriants.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: I, and their Yeoman too.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Nay fayth Acquaintance, let me tell you, you forgat your selfe too much: we had excellent cheere, rare vintage, and were drunke after supper.

sp.speaker: Pior.
sp.p: And when wee were in our Woodcocks (sweete Rogue) a brace of Gulles, dwelling here in the City, came in & payd all the shot.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pox on her, let her alone.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O, I pray doe, if you be Gentlemen:
I pray depart the house; beshrew the dore
For being so easily entreated: fayth,
I lent but little eare vnto your talke,
My mind was busied otherwise in troth,
And so your words did vnregarded passe:
Let this suffice, I am not as I was.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: I am not what I was! no Ile be sworne thou art not: for thou wert honest at fiue, & now th'art a Puncke at fifteene: thou wert yesterday a simple whore, and now th'art a cunning Conny-catching Baggage to day.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ile say I me worse, I pray forsake me then,
I doe desire you leaue me, Gentlemen,
And leaue your selues: O be not what you are,
(Spendthrifts of soule and body)
Let me perswade you to forsake all Harlots,
Worse then the deadliest poysons, they are worse:
For o're their soules hangs an eternall curse,
In being slaues to slaues, their labours perish,
Th'are seldome blest with fruit; for ere it blossoms,
Many a worme confounds it.
They haue no issue but foule vgly ones,
That run along with them, e'ene to their graues:
For stead of children, they breed ranke diseases,
And all, you Gallants, can bestow on them,
Is that French Infant, which n'ere acts but speaks:
What shallow sonne & heire then, foolish gallant,
Would waste all his inheritance, to purchase
A filthy loathd disease? and pawne his body
To a dry euill: that vsurie's worst of all,
When th'interest will eate out the principall.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sfoot, she guls em the best: this is alwaies her fashion, when she would be rid of any company that she cares not for, to inioy mine alone.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Whats here? instructions, Admonitions, and Caueats? come out, you scabberd of vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Fluello, spurne your hounds when they fyste, you shall not spurne my Punk, I can tell you my bloud is vext.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Pox a your bloud: make it a quarrell.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Y'are a Slaue, will that serue turne?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Sbloud, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Matheo, Fluello, for shame put vp.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Spurne my sweet Varlet!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O how many thus
Mou'd with a little folly, haue let out
Their soules in Brothell houses, fell downe and dyed
Iust at their Harlots foot, as 'twere in pride.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Matheo, we shall meet.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I, I, any where, sauing at Church: pray take heed we meet not there.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Adue, Damnation.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Cockatrice, farewell.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: There's more deceit in women, then in hel. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, thou doest gull em so rarely, so naturally: if I did not think thou hadst bin in earnest: thou art a sweet Rogue for't ifayth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why are not you gone to, Signior Matheo?
I pray depart my house: you may beleeue me,
In troth I haue no part of Harlot in me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Indeed I loue you not: but hate you worse
Then any man, because you were the first
Gaue money for my soule; you brake the Ice,
Which after turnd a puddle: I was led
By your temptation to be miserable:
I pray seeke out some other that will fall,
Or rather (I pray) seeke out none at all.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ist possible, to be impossible, an honest whore! I haue heard many honest wenches turne Strumpets with a wet finger; but for a Harlot to turne honest, is one of Hercules labours: It was more easie for him in one night to make fifty queanes, then to make one of them honest agen in fifty yeeres: come, I hope thou doost but iest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Tis time to leaue off iesting, I had almost
Iested away Saluation: I shall loue you,
If you will soone forsake me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: God buy thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Oh, tempt no more women: shun their weighty curse,
Women (at best) are bad, make them not worse,
You gladly seeke our sexes ouerthrow:
But not to rayse our states for all your wrongs.
Will you vouchsafe me but due recompence,
To marry with me?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How, marry with a Punck, a Cockatrice, a Harlot? mary foh, Ile be burnt thorow the nose first.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why la? these are your othes you loue to vndo vs,
To put heauen from vs, whilst our best houres waste:
You loue to make vs lewd, but neuer chaste.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ile heare no more of this: this ground vpon,
Th'art damn'd for altring thy Religion. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thy lust and sin speake so much: go thou my ruine,
The first fall my soule tooke; by my example
I hope few maydens now will put their heads
Vnder mens girdels: who least trusts, is most wise:
Mens othes do cast a mist before our eyes.
My best of wit be ready: now I goe,
By some deuice to greet Hipolito.

div.head: SCENA 10.
div.stage: Enter a seruant setting out a Table, on which be places a scull, a picture, a booke and a Taper.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: So, this is Monday morning, and now must I to my huswifry: would I had bin created a Shoomaker; for all the gentle craft are gentlemen euery Monday by their Copy, & scorne (then) to worke one true stitch. My M. meanes sure to turne me into a student; for here's my booke, here my deske, here my light; this my close chamber, and heere my Punck: so that this dull drowzy first day of the weeke, makes me halfe a Priest, halfe a Chandler, halfe a paynter, halfe a Sexton, I & halfe a Bawd: for (all this day) my office is to do nothing but keep the dore. To proue it, looke you, this good-face & yonder gentleman (so soone as euer my back's turnd) wil be naught together. Enter Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Are all the windowes shut?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Close sir, as the fist of a Courtier that hath stood in three raignes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Thou art a faythfull seruant, and obseru'st
The Calender, both of my solemne vowes,
And ceremonious sorrow: Get thee gone,
I charge thee on thy life, let not the sound
Of any womans voyce pierce through that dore.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: If they do, my Lord, Ile pearce some of them.
What will your Lordship haue to breakfast?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Sighs.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: What to dinner?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Teares.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The one of them, my Lord, will fill you too full of wind, the other wet you too much. What to supper?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: That which (now) thou canst not get me, the constancy of a woman.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Indeed thats harder to come by then euer was Ostend.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Prythee away.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Ile make away my selfe presently, which few Seruants will doe for their Lords; but rather helpe to make them away: Now to my dore-keeping, I hope to picke something out of it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My Infelices face: her brow, her eye,
The dimple on her cheeke: and such sweet skill,
Hath from the cunning workemans pencill flowne,
These lippes looke fresh and liuely as her owne,
Seeming to mooue and speake. Las I now I see,
The reason why fond women loue to buy
Adulterate complexion: here 'tis read,
False coulours last after the true be dead.
Of all the Roses grafted on her cheekes,
Of all the graces dauncing in her eyes,
Of all the Musick set vpon her tongue,
Of all that was past womans excellence,
In her white bosome, looke! a painted board,
Circumscribes all: Earth can no blisse affoord.
Nothing of her, but this? this cannot speake,
It has no lap for me to rest vpon,
No lip worth tasting: here the wormes will feed,
As in her coffin: hence then idle Art,
True loue's best picturde in a true-loues heart.
Here art thou drawne sweet maid, till this be dead,
So that thou liu'st twice, twice art buried.
Thou figure of my friend, lye there. Whats here?
Perhaps this shrewd pate was mine enimies:
Las! say it were: I need not feare him now:
For all his braues, his contumelious breath,
His frownes (tho dagger-pointed) all his plot,
(Tho' nere so mischieuous) his Italian pilles,
His quarrels, and (that common fence) his law,
See, see, they're all eaten out; here's not left one?
How cleane they're pickt away! to the bare bone!
How mad are mortals then to reare great names
On tops of swelling houses? or to weare out
Their fingers ends (in durt,) to scrape vp gould!
Not caring so (that Sumpter-horse) the back
Be hung with gawdy trappings, with what course,
Yea rags most beggerly, they cloath the soule:
Yet (after all) their Gay-nes lookes thus foule.
What fooles are men to build a garish tombe,
Onely to saue the carcasse whilst it rots,
To maintein't long in stincking, make good carion,
But leaue no good deeds to preserue them sound,
For good deedes keepe men sweet, long aboue ground,
And must all come to this; fooles; wise, all hether,
Must all heads thus at last be laid together:
Draw me my picture then, thou graue neate workeman,
After this fashion, not like this; these coulours
In time kissing but ayre, will be kist off,
But heres a fellow; that which he layes on,
Till doomes day, alters not complexion.
Death's' the best Painter then: They that draw shapes,
And liue by wicked faces, are but Gods Apes,
They come but neere the life, and there they stay,
This fellow drawes life to: his Art is fuller,
The pictures which he makes are without coulour.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's a person would speake with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A parson sir would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Vicar?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Vicar? no sir, has too good a face to be a Vicar yet, a youth, a very youth.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What youth? of man or woman? lock the dores.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: If it be a woman, mary-bones and Potato pies keepe me for medling with her, for the thing has got the breeches, tis a male-varlet sure my Lord, for a womans tayler nore measurd him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Let him giue thee his message and be gone.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He sayes hees signior Mathaeos man, but I know he lyes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How doest thou know it?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Cause has nere a beard: tis his boy I thinke sir, whosoere paide for his nursing.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Send him and keepe the doore. Reades.
Fata si liceat mihi,
Fingere arbitrio meo,
Temperem Zephyro leuivela.
Ide saile were I to choose, not in the Ocean,
Cedars are shaken, when shrubs doe feele no bruize▪
How? from Mathaeo.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Art sick?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Not all in health my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Keepe off.

sp.speaker: Belle.
sp.l: I do:
Hard fate when women are compeld to wooe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: This paper does speake nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes my Lord,
Matter of life it speakes, and therefore writ
In hidden Caracter; to me instruction
My maister giues, And (lesse you please to stay
Till you both meet) I can the text display.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Doe so: read out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I am already out:
Looke on my face, and read the strangest story!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What villaine, ho? Enter his seruant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Call you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Thou slaue, thou hast let in the diuell.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Lord blesse vs, where? hees not clouen my Lord that I can see: besides the diuell goes more like a Gentleman than a Page: good my Lord Boon couragio.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Thou hast let in a woman in mans shape.
And thou art dambd for't.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Not dambd I hope for putting in a woman to a Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fetch me my Rapier,— do not: I shall kill thee.
Purge this infected chamber of that plague,
That runnes vpon me thus: Slaue, thrust her hence.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, I shall neuer be able to thrust her hence without helpe: come Mermaid you must to Sea agen.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Here me but speake, my words shall be all Musick:
Here me but speake.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Another beates the dore,
T'other Shee-diuell, looke.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why then hell's broke loose. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Hence, guard the chamber: let no more come on,
One woman serues for mans damnation.
Beshrew thee, thou doost make me violate,
The chastest and most sanctimonious vow,
That ere was entred in the court of heauen:
I was on meditations spottles wings,
vpon my iorney thether; like a storme
Thou beats my ripened cogitations,
flat to the ground: and like a theife doost stand,
To steale deuotion from the holy land.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If woman were thy mother; if thy hart,
Bee not all Marble, (or ift Marble be)
Let my teares soften it, to pitty me,
I doe beseech the doe not thus with scorne,
Destroy a woman.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Woman I beseech thee,
Get thee some other suite, this fits thee not,
I would not grant it to a kneeling Queene,
I cannot loue thee, nor I must not: See,
The copy of that obligation,
Where my soule's bound in heauy penalties.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She's dead you told me, shele let fal her suite.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My vowes to her, fled after her to heauen,
Were thine eyes cleere as mine, thou mightst behold her,
Watching vpon yon battlements of starres,
How I obserue them: should I breake my bond,
This bord would riue in twaine, these wooden lippes
Call me most periurde villaine, let it suffice,
I ha set thee in the path; Ist not a signe,
I loue thee, when with one so most most deare,
Ile haue thee fellowes? All are fellowes there.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be greater then a king, saue not a body,
But from eternall shipwracke keepe a soule,
If not, and that againe, sinnes path I tread,
The griefe be mine, the guilt fall on thy head.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Stay and take Phisicke for it, read this booke,
Aske counsell of this head whats to be done,
Hele strike it dead that tis damnation,
If you turne turke againe, oh doe it not,
The heauen cannot allure you to doe well
From doing ill let hell fright you: and learne this,
The soule whose bosome lust did neuer touch,
Is Gods faire bride, and maidens soules are such:
The soule that leauing chastities white shore,
Swims in hot sensuall streames, is the diuels whore,
How now: who comes. Enter his seruant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No more knaues my Lord that weare smocks: heres a letter from doctor Benedict; I would not enter his man, tho he had haires at his mouth, for feare he should be a woman, for some women haue beardes, mary they are halfe witches, Slid you are a sweete youth to weare a codpeece, and haue no pinnes to sticke vpont.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Ile meete the doctor, tell him, yet to night
I cannot: but at morrow rising Sunne
I will not faile: go: woman fare thee well. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The lowest fall can be but into hell,
It does not moue him. I must therefore fly,
From this vndoing Cittie, and with teares,
Wash off all anger from my fathers brow,
He cannot sure but ioy seeing me new borne,
A woman honest first and then turne whore,
Is (as with me) common to thousands more,
But from a strumpet to turne chast: that sound,
Has oft bin heard, that woman hardly found. Exit.

div.head: 11. SCE.

sp.speaker: Fus.
sp.p: Hold vp your hands gentlemen: heres one, two, three, (nay I warrant they are sound pistols, and without flawes, I had them (of my sister, and I know she vses to put nothing thats crackt,) three, foure, fiue, sixe, seuen, eight and nine, by this hand bring me but a piece of his bloud. and you shall haue 9. more. Ile lurke in a tauerne not far off, & prouide supper to close vp the end of the Tragedy, the linnen drapers remēber-stand toot I beseech you, & play your partes perfectly.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Looke you Signior, tis not your golde that we way.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.l: Nay, nay, way it and spare not, if it lacke one graine of corne;
Ile giue you a bushell of wheate to make it vp.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
But by your fauour Signior, which of the seruants
is it, because wele punish iustly.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Mary tis the head man; you shall rast him by his tongue a pretty tall prating felow, with a Tuscalonian beard.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Tuscalonian: very good.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Cods life I was neere so thrumbd since I was a gentleman: my coxcombe was dry beaten as if my haire had beene hemp.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Wele dry beate some of them.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nay it grew so high, that my sister cryed murder out very manfully: I haue her consent in a manner to haue him pepperd, els ile not doot to win more then ten cheaters do at a rifling: breake but his pate or so, onely his mazer, because ile haue his head in a cloath aswell as mine, hees a linnen draper and may take enough. I could enter mine action of battery against him, but we may haps be both dead and rotten before the lawyers would end it.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: No more to doe, but insconce your selfe i'th taueren; prouide no great cheate, couple of Capons, some Phesants, Plouers, an Oringeado-pie or so: but how bloudy so ere the day be, sally you not forth.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: No, no, nay if I stir, some body shal stinke: ile not budge: ile lie like a dog in a manger.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Well, well, to the tauerne, let not our supper be raw, for you shall haue blood enough-your belly full.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Thats all so god same, I thirst after, bloud for bloud, bump for bump, nose for nose, head for head, plaster for plaster, and so farewell: what shall I call your names because ile leaue word, if any such come to the barre.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: My name is Corporall Crambo.

sp.speaker: Poh.
sp.p: and mine, Lieutenant Poh. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Poli. Is as tall a man as euer opened Oyster: I would not be the diuell to meete Poh, farewell.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nor I by this light, if Poh be such a Poh. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Condidoes wife, in her shop, and the two Premises.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What's a clocke now.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: Tis almost 12.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Thats well.
The Senate will leaue wording presently:
But is George ready,

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, hees surbusht.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Now as you euer hope to win my fauour,
Throw both your duties and respects on him,
With the like awe as if he were your maister,
Let not your lookes betray it with a smile,
Or ieering glaunce to any customer,
Keepe a true Setled countenance, and beware,
You laugh not whatsoeuer you heare or see.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: I warrant you mistris, let vs alone for keeping our countenance: for if I list, theres neuer a foole in all Myllan shal make me laugh, let him play the foole neuer so like an Asse, whether it be the fat Court foole, or the leane Cittie foole.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: enough then, call downe George.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: I heare him comming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Be redy with your legs then let me see,
How curtzy would become him: gallantly!
Beshrew my bloud a proper seemely man,
Of a choice carriage walkes with a good port,

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I thanke you mistris, my back's broad enough, now my Maisters gown's on.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Sure I should thinke it were the least of sin,
To mistake the maister, and to let him in.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Twere a good Comedy of errors that yfaith.

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.p: whist, whist, my maister.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: You all know your taskes: gods my life, whats that hee has got vpon's backe? who can tell?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That can I, but I will not.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Girt about him like a mad-man: what: has he lost his cloake too: this is the maddest fashion that ere I saw.

lg.l: What said he George when he pasde by thee?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Troth Mistris nothing: not so much as a Bee, he did not hum: not so much as a bawd he did not hem: not so much as a Cuekold he did not ha: neither hum, hem, nor ha, onely starde me in the face, past along, and made hast in, as if my lookes had workt with him, to giue him a stoole.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Sure hees vext now, this trick has mou'd his Spleene,
Hees angred now, because he vttred nothing:
And wordlesse wrath breakes out more violent,
May be heele striue for place, when he comes downe,
But if thou lou'st me George, affoord him none.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay let me alone to play my maisters prize, as long as my Mistrisse warrants me: Ime sure I haue his best clothes on, and I scorne to giue place to any that is inferiour in apparell to me, thats an Axiom, a principle, & is obseru'd as much as the fashion; let that perswade you then, that lie shoulder with him for the vpper hand in the shop, as long as this chaine will mainteine it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Spoke with the spirit of a Maister, tho with the tongue of a Prentise.
Why how now mad-man? what in your tricksicoates!

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: O peace good Mistrisse: Enter Crambo and Poli. See what you lack, what ist you buy? pure Callicoes, fine Hollands, choise Cambrickes, neate Lawnes: see what you buy? pray come neere, my Maister will vse you well, hee can affoord you a pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: I that he can, out of a whole peece of Lawne yfaith.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Pray see your choise here Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: O fine foole? what a mad-man? a patient mad-man? who euer heard of the like? well sir Ile fit you and your humour presently: what? crosse-points, Ile vntie em all in a trice, Ile vex you faith: Boy take your cloake, quick, come. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Be couered George, this chaine, and welted gowne, Bare to this coate: then the worlds vpside downe.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Vmh, vmh, hum.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Thats the shop, and theres the fellow.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: I but the Maister is walking in there.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: No matter, weele in.

sp.speaker: Poh.
sp.p: Sbloud doest long to lye in Limbo?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: And Limbo be in hell, I care not.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Looke you Gentlemen, your choise: Cambricks?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: No sir, some shirting.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Haue you none of this strip'd Canuas for doublets.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: None strip'd sir, but plaine.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: I thinke there be one peece strip'd within.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Step sirra and fetch it, hum, hum hum.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Looke you Gentlemen, Ile make but one spredding, heres a peece of cloth, fine, yet shall weare like Yron, tis without fault, take this vpon my word, tis without fault.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Then tis better than you sirra.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I, and a number more, ô that each soule
Were but as spotlesse as this Innocent white,
And had as few brakes in it.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Twould haue some then: there was a fray here last day in this shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: There was indeed a little flea-biting.

sp.speaker: Poh.
sp.p: A Gentleman had his pate broake, call you that but a flea-biting.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: He had so.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Zownes doe you stand in't? He strikes him.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Sfoot clubs, clubs, prentices, downe with em, ah you roagues, strike a Citizen in's shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: None of you stir I pray, forbeare good George.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: I beseech you sir, we mistooke our markes, delivers vs our weapons.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your head bleeds sir, cry clubs.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I say you shall not, pray be patient,
Giue them their weapons, sirs you're best be gone,
I tell you here are boyes more tough then Beares:
Hence, least more fists do walke about your eares.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We thanke you sir. Exeunt,

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: You shall not follow them.
Let them alone pray, this did me no harme,
Troth I was cold, and the blow made me warme,
I thanke em for't: besides I had decreed
To haue a vaine prickt, I did meane to bleede,
So that theres mony sau'd: they are honest men,
Pray vse em well, when they appeare agen.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes sir, weele vse em like honest men.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I well said George, like honest men, tho they be arrant knaues, for thats the praise of the citty; helpe to lay vp these wares

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yonder he stands.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.p: What in a Prentise-coate?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I, I, mad, mad, pray take heed.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: How now? what newes with them? what make they with my wife? officers is she attachd? looke to your wares.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: He talkes to himselfe, oh hees much gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Pray pluck vp a good heart, be not so fearfull,
Sirs hearke, weele gather to him by degrees.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: I, I, by degrees I pray: oh me! what makes he with the Lawne in his hand, heele teare all the ware in my shop.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Feare not weele catch him on a sudden.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: O you had need do so, pray take heed of your warrant

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: I warrant mistris.— Now Signior Candido?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Now sir, what newes with you sir?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: What newes with you he sayes: oh hees far gon.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I pray feare nothing, lets alone with him,
Signior, you looke not like your selfe me thinkes,
(Steale you a tother side) y'are changde, y'are altred.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Changde sir, why true sir, is change strange, tis not the fashion vnlesse it alter: Monarkes turne to beggers; beggers creepe into the nests of Princes, Maisters serue their prentises: Ladies their Seruingmen, men turne to women.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.l: And women turne to men.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I, and women turne to men, you say true, ha ha, a mad world, a mad world.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Haue we caught you sir?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Caught me: well, well: you haue caught: me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Hee laughes in your faces.

sp.speaker: Geo
sp.p: A rescue Prentises, my maister's catch-pold.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: I charge you keepe the peace, or haue your legs gartered with Yrons, we haue from the Duke a warrant strong enough for what we doe.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I pray rest quiet, I desire no rescue.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: La: he desires no rescue, I as poore heart,
He talkes against himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Well, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Looke to that arme,
Pray make sure worke, double the cord.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Why, why?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Looke how his head goes! should he get but loose,
Oh twere as much as all our liues were worth.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Feare not, weele make all sure for our owne safetie.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Are you at leisure now? well, whats the matter?
Why do I enter into bonds thus? ha?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Because y'are mad, put feare vpon your wife.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Oh I, I went in danger of my life, euery minute.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: What? am I mad say you, and I not know it?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: That proues you mad, because you know it not.

sp.speaker: Wif
sp.l: Pray talke as little to him as you can,
You see hees too farre spent.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Bound with strong corde,
A Cisters thred yfaith had beene enough,
To lead me any where: Wife do you long?
You are mad too, or els you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: But are you mad indeed Maister?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: My Wife sayes so,
And what she sayes; George, is all trueth you know:
And whether now? to Bethlem Monastery?— ha! whether?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Faith eene to the mad-mens pound.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: A Gods name, still I feele my patience sound. Exe.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Come weele see whether he goes, if the maister be mad, we are his seruants, and must follow his steps, weele be mad caps too; Farewell mistrisse, you shall haue vs all in Bedlam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I thinke, I ha fitted now, you and your clothes,
If this moue not his patience, nothing can,
Ile sweare then I haue a saint, and not a man Exit.

div.head: 13. SCE.
div.stage: Enter Duke: Doctor: Fluello, Castruchio, Pioratto.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: giue vs a little leaue. Doctor your newes.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I sent for him my Lord: at last he came,
And did receiue all speech that went from me,
As gilded pilles made to prolong his health:
My credit with him wrought it: for, some men.
Swallow euen empty hookes, like fooles. that feare
No drowning where tis deepest, Cause tis cleare:
In th'end we sat and eate: a health I dranke
To Infaelices sweete departed soule,
(This traine I knew would take.)

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Twas excellent.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: He fell with such deuotion on his knees,
To pledge the same.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Fond superstitious foole?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: That had he beene inflam'd with zeale of prayer,
He could not power't out with more reuerence.
About my necke he hung, wept on my cheeke,
Kist it, and swore, he would adore my lippes,
Because they brought forth Infaelices name.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Ha, ha, alacke, alacke.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: The cup he lifs vp high, and thus he said,
Here noble maid: drinkes, and was poisoned.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: and died?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: And died my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Thou in that word,
Hast peicd mine aged houres out with more yeares,
Than thou hast taken from Hipolito,
A noble youth he was, but lesser branches
Hindring the greaters growth, must be lopt off,
And feede the fire: Doctor w'are now all thine,
And vse vs so: be bold.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Thankes gracious Lord:
My honoured Lord:

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: hmh.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I doe beseech your grace to bury deepe,
This bloudy act of mine.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Nay, nay, for that,
Doctor looke you toot: me it shall not moue,
Their curst that ill doe, not that ill do loue,

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: You throw an angry forehead on my face,
But be you pleas'd, backward thus for to looke,
That for your good, this euill I vndertooke,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I, I, we conster so:

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: And onely for your loue.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Confest: tis true.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Nor let it stand against me as a bar,
To thrust me from your presence: nor beleeue
(As Princes haue quicke thoughts,) that now my finger
Being deept in blood, I will not spare the hand,
But that for gold (as what can golde not doe?)
I may be hi'rde to worke the like on you,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Which to preuent.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Tis from my hart as far.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No matter Doctor, cause ile feareles sleepe,
And that you shall stand cleare of that suspition
I banish thee for euer from my court.
This principle is olde but true as fate,
Kings may loue treason, but the traitor hate, Exit.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Ist so: nay then Duke, your stale principle
With one as stale, the Doctor thus shall quit,
He fals himselfe that digs anothers pit,
How now: where is he? will he meete me:

sp.speaker: Doc. man,
sp.p: meete you sir, he might haue met with three fencers in this time and haue receiued lesse hurt then by meeting one Doctor of Phisicke: why sir has walkt vnder the olde Abbey wall yonder this houre, till hees more colde then a Cittizens country house in Ianiuere, you may smell him behinde sir; la you: yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: leaue me. Enter Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Doc. man.
sp.l: Itch lurch if you will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: O my most noble friend.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Few but your selfe,
Could haue intied me thus, to trust the Aire,
With my close sighes, you send for me: what newes?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Come you must doff this blacke: die that pale cheeke,
Into his owne colour; goe: Attire your selfe
Fresh as a bridegroome, when he meetes his bride,
The Duke has done much treason to thy loue,
Tis now reuealed, tis now to be reuengde,
Be mery honord friend, thy Lady liues.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Infaelice, Shees reuiude;
Reuiude: alacke! death neuer had the hart,
To take breath from her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Vmh: I thanke you sir,
Phisicke prolongs life, when it cannot saue,
This helpes not my hopes. mine are in their graue:
You doe some wrong to mocke me.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: By that loue,
Which I haue euer borne you, what I speake
Is trueth: the maiden liues: that funerall,
Dukes teares, the morning, was all counterfet,
A sleepy draught cozend the world and you,
I was his minister and then chambred vp,
To stop discouery.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O trecherous Duke:

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: He cannot hope so certainely for blisse:
As he beleeues that I haue poysond you,
He wode me toot, I yeelded, and confirm'd him,
In his most bloudy thoughts.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A very deuill!

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Her did he closely coach to Bergamo,
And thither?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Will I ride, stood Bergamo,
In the low countries of blacke hell, ile to her.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: You shall to her, but not to Bergamo,
How passion makes you fly beyond your selfe.
Much of that weary iourney iha cut off,
For she by letters hath intelligence,
Of your supposed death, her owne interment,
And all those plots, which that false Duke, (her father)
Has wrought against you: And sheele meete you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O when:

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Nay see: how couetous are your desires,
Easely to morrow morne.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O where good father.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: At Bethlem monasterie: are you pleasd now?

sp.speaker: Hip,
sp.l: At Bethlem monasterie: the place well fits,
It is the scoole where those that loose their wits,
Practise againe to get them: I am sicke
Of that disease, all loue is lunaticke.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Weele steale away, this night in some disguise,
Father Anselmo, a most reuerend Frier,
Expects our comming, before whom weele lay,
Reasons so strong, that he shall yeeld, in bonds,
Oh holy wedlocke, to tie both your hands.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: This is such happinesse:
That to beleeue it, tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Let all your ioyes then die in misbeliefe,
I will reueale no more.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O yes good father,
I am so well acquainted with despaire,
I know not how to hope: I beleeue all.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Weele hence this night, much must be done, much said
But if the Doctor faile not in his charmes,
Your Lady shall ere morning fill these armes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: heauenly Phisition: far thy fame shall sprede,
That mak'st two louers speake when they be dead.

div.stage: Candido's wife, and George: Pioratto meetes them.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: O watch good George, watch which way the Duke comes.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Here comes one of the butter flies, aske him.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Pray sir, comes the duke this way.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: He's vpon comming mistris. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: I thanke you sir: George are there many madfolkes, where thy Maister lies.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: O yes, of all countries some, but especially mad greekes they swarme: troth mistris, the world is altered with you, you had not wont to stand thus with a paper humblie complaining: but you're well enough seru'd: prouander prickt you, as it does many of our Cittie-wiues besides.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Doest thinke George we shall get him forth.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Truly mistris I cannot tel, I thinke youle hardly get him forth: why tis strange! Sfoot I haue known many women that haue had mad rascals to their husbands, whom they would belabour by all meanes possible to keepe em in their right wits, but of a woman to long to turne a tame man into a madman, why the diuell himselfe was neuer vsde so by his dam.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: How does he talke George! ha! good George tell me.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Why youre best go see.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Alas I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Afraid! you had more need be ashamd: he may rather be afraid of you.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: But George hees not starke mad, is hee? hee does not raue, hees not horne-mad George is he?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay I know not that, but he talkes like a Iustice of peace, of a thousand matters and to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Ile to the monastery: I shall be mad till I inioy him, I shalbe sick till I see him, yet when I doe see him, I shall weepe out mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I, ide faine see a woman weepe out her eyes; thats as true, as to say, a mans cloake burnes; when it hangs in the water: I know youle weepe mistrisse, but what saies the painted cloth.

lg.l: Trust not a woman when she cryes,
For sheele pump water from her eyes,
With a wet finger, and in faster showers,
Then Aprill when he raines downe flowers.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I but George, that painted cloath is worthy to be hangd vp for lying, all women haue not teares at will, vnlesse they haue good cause.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I but mistrisse how easily will they find a cause, and as one of our Cheese-trenchers sayes very learnedly:

lg.l: As out of Wormwood Bees suck Hony,
As from poore clients Lawyers firke mony,
As Parsley from a roasted cunny.
So tho the day be nere so sunny,
If wiues will haue it raine, downe then it driues,
The calmest husbands make the stormest wiues,

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Tame George, but I had on storming now.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Why thats well done, good mistris throw aside this fashion of your humor, be not so phantasticall in wearing it, storme no more, long no more.— This longing has made you come short of many a good thing that you might haue had from my Maister: Here comes the Duke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Oh I beseech you pardon my offence,
In that I durst abuse your Graces warrant,
Deliuer foorth my husband good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who is her husband?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Candido my Lord,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Hees among the lunaticks,
He was a man made vp without a gall,
Nothing could moue him, nothing could conuert
His meeke bloud into fury, yet like a monster,
I often beate at the most constant rock
Of his vnshaken patience, and did long
To vex him.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Did you so?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And for that purpose,
Had warrant from your Grace, to cary him
To Bethlem Monastery, whence they will not free him,
Without your Graces hand that sent him in.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You haue longd fayre; tis you are mad I feare,
Its fit to fetch him thence, and keepe you there:
If he be mad, why would you haue him forth?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And please your grace, hees not starke mad, but onely talkes like a young Gentleman, somewhat phantastically, thats all: theres a thousand about your court, citty and countrie madder then he.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Prouide a warrant, you shall haue our hand.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Heres a warrant ready drawne my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Get pen & Inck, get pen & inck: Enter Castruchio.

sp.speaker: Cast
sp.p: Where is my Lord the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How now? more mad men.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I haue strange newes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Of what? of whom?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Of Infaelice, and a mariage.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Ha! where? with whom.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Hence with that woman, voyd the roome.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Away, the Duke's vext.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Whoop, come mistris the Duke's mad too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Who told me that Hipolito was dead?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: He that can make any man dead, the Doctor: but my Lord, hees as full of life as wilde-fire, and as quick: Hipolito, the Doctor, and one more rid hence this euening; the Inne at which they light is Bethlem Monastarie: Infaeliche comes from Bergamo, and meetes them there: Hipolito is mad, for he meanes this day to be maryed, the after-noone is the houre, and Frier Anselmo is the knitter.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: From Bergamo? ist possible? it cannot be,
It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I will not sweare my Lord,
But this intelligence I tooke from one,
Whose braines workes in the plot.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Whats he?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Mathaeo.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Mathaeo knowes all.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Hees Hipolitoes bosome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How farre stands Bethlem hence?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Six or seauen miles.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ist euen so, not maried till the afternoone you say?
Stay, stay, lets worke out some preuention: how:
This is most strange, can none but mad-men serue
To dresse their wedding dinner? All of you,
Get presently to horse; disguise your selues
Like Countrie-Gentlemen,
Or riding cittizens, or so: and take
Each man a seuerall path, but let vs meete,
At Bethlem Monasterie, some space of time
Being spent betweene the arriuall each of other,
As if we came to see the Lunaticks.
To horse, away, be secret on your liues,
Loue must be punisht that vniustly thriues. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Be secret on your liues! Castruchio
Y'are but a scuruy Spaniell; honest Lord,
Good Lady: Zounds their loue is iust, tis good,
And Ile preuent you, tho I swim in bloud. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Frier Anselmo, Hipolito, Mathaeo, Infaeliche.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Nay, nay, resolue good father, or deny.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You presse me to an act, both full of danger,
And full of happinesse, for I behold.
Your fathers frownes, his threats, nay perhaps death,
To him that dare doe this, yet noble Lord,
Such comfortable beames breake through these clowdes,
By this blest mariage, that your honord word
Being pawnd in my defence) I will tie fast,
The holy wedding Knot.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Tush feare not the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O sonne, wisely to feare: Is to be free from feare.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You haue our words, and you shall haue our liues,
To guard you safe from all ensuing danger.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I, I, chop em vp and away.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Stay, when ist fit for me, safest for you,
To entertaine this busines.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Not till the euening.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Be't so, there is a chappell stands hard by,
Vpon the West end of the Abbey wall,
Thether conuay your selues, and when the sunne
Hath turnd his back vpon this vpper world,
Ile mary you, that done, no thundring voice,
Can breake the sacred bond, yet Lady here you are most safe.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Father your lou's most deere.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I well said locke vs into some little roome by our selues that we may be mad for an houre or two.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O good Mathaeo no, lets make no noise.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
How! no noise! do you know where you are: sfoot amonst all the mad-caps in Millan: so that to throw the house out at window will be the better, & no man will suspect that we lurke here to steale mutton: the more sober we are, the more scuruy tis. And tho the Frier tell vs, that heere we are safest, i'me not of his minde, for if those lay here that had lost there mony, none would euer looke after them, but heare are none but those that haue lost their wits, o that if hue and cry be made, hether theile come, and my reason is, because none
goes to be married till he be starke mad.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Muffle your selues yonders Fluello. Enter Fluello.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Zounds!

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: O my Lord these cloakes are not for this raine, the tempest is too great: I come sweating to tell you of it, that you may get out of it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Why whats the matter.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Whats the matter! you haue matterd it faire: the Duk's at hand.

sp.speaker: Onm.
sp.l: The Duke?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: The very Duke.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Then all our plots are turnd vpon our heads; and we are blown vp with our own vnderminings. Sfoot how comes he, what villaine durst betray our being here.

sp.speaker: Flu:
sp.p: Castruchio, Castruchio tolde the Duke, and Mathaeo here told Castruchio.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Would you betray me to Castruchio,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sfoot he dambd himselfe to the pit of hell if he spake ont agen.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: So did you sweare to me, so were you dambd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pox on em, & there be no faith in men, if a man shall not beleeue oathes: he tooke bread and salt by this light, that he would neuer open his lips.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Oh God, oh God.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Sonne be not desperate haue patience, you shal trip your enemy downe, by his owne slights, how far is the Duke hence.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Hees but new set out: Castruchio, Pioratto and Sinezi come along with him: you haue time enough yet to preuent them if you haue but courage.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You shall steale secretly into the Chappell,
And presently be maried; if the duke
Abide here still, spite of ten thousand eyes,
You shall scape hence like Friers.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O blest disguisde: O happy man.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Talke not of happinesse till your closde hand,
Haue her byth' forhead, like the lock of time,
Bee not too slow, nor hasty, now you clime,
Vp to the towre of blisse, onely be wary
And patient, thats all, if you like my plot
Build and dispatch, if not farewell, then not.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O Yes, we doe applaud it, weele dispute,
No longer, but will hence and execute.
Fluello youle stay here, let vs be gon,
The ground that fraighted louers tread vpon,
Is stuke with thornes.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Come then, away: tis meete,
To escape those thornes, to put on winged feete. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No words I pray Fluello, for it stands vs vpon.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Oh sir, let that be your lesson.
Alas poore louers, on what hopes and feares,
Men tosse themselues for women. when shees got
The best has in her that which pleaseth not.

div.stage: Enter to Fluello, the Duke, Castruchio, Pioratto and Sinezi from seuerall dores muffled.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: whos's there!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Peace, send that Lord away,
A Lordship will spoile all, lets be all fellowes.
Whats he.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Fluello, or els Sinezi by his little legs.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: All friends, all friends.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What! met vpon the very point of time,
Is this the place.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: This is the place my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dreame you on Lordships! come no more Lordes: pray
You haue not seene these louers yet.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Castruchio art thou sure this wedding feate,
Is not till afternoone?

sp.speaker: Castr.
sp.l: So tis giuen out my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Nay, nay, tis like, theeues must obserue their houres,
Louers watch minuts like Astronomers,
How shall the Interim houres by vs be spent,

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Lets all goe see the madmen.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Mas content. Enter Towne like a sweeper.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Oh here comes one, question him, question him.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: How now honest fellow dost thou belong to the house.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: yes forsooth, I am one of the implements; I swepe the madmens roomes, and fetch straw for em, and buy chaines to tie em, and rods to whip em, I was a mad wag my selfe here once, but I thanke father Anselm he lasht me into my right minde agen.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Anselmo is the Frier must marry them,
Question him where he is,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: And where is father Anselmo now?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Mary hees gon but eene now.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: I, well done, tell me, whether is he gone?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Why to God a mighty.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, this fellow is a foole, talkes idlelie.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Sirra are all the mad folkes in Millan brought hither?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: How all, theres a wise question indeede: why if al the mad folkes in Millan should come hither, there would not be left ten men in the Citty.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Few gentlemen or Courtiers here, ha.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Oh yes? abundance, aboundance, lands no sooner fall into their hands, but straight they runne out a their wits: Citizens sons & heires are free of the house by their fathers copy: Farmers sons come hither like geese (in flocks) & when they ha sould all their corne fields, here they sit & picke the straws.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: Me thinks you should haue women here aswel as men.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Oh, I: a plague on em, theres no ho with them, they are madder then march haires.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Are there no lawyers here amongst you?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Oh no, not one: neuer any lawyer, we dare not let a lawyer come in, for heele make em mad faster than we can recouer em.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And how long ist er'e you recouer any of these.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Why according to the quantitie of the Moone thats got into em, an Aldermans sonne will be mad a great while a very great while, especially if his friends left him well, a whore will hardly come to her wits agen: a puritane ther's no hope of him, vnlesse he may pull downe the steeple and hang himselfe it'h bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: I perceiue all sorts of fish come to your net.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Yes in truth, we haue blockes for all heads, we haue good store of wilde oates here: for the Courtier is mad at the Cittizen, the Cittizen is madde at the Country men, the shoomaker is mad at the cobler, the cobler at the carman the punke is mad that the Marchants wife is no whore, the Marchants wife is mad that the puncke is so common a whore: gods so, heres father Anselmo. pray say nothing that I tel tales out of the schoole. Exit.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: God blesse you father. Enter Anselmo.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Thanke you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Pray may we see some of those wretched Soules,
That here are in your keeping?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Yes: you shall,
But gentlemen I must disarme you then,
There are of mad men, as there are of tame,
All humourd not alike: we haue here some,
So apish and phantastike, play with a fether,
And tho twould greeue a soule, to see Gods image,
So blemisht and defac'd, yet do they act
Such anticke and such pretty lunacies,
That spite of sorrow they will make you smile:
Others agen we haue like hungry Lions,
Fierce as wilde Buls, vntameable as flies,
And these haue oftentimes from strangers sides
Snatcht rapiers suddenly, and done much harme,
Whom if youle see, you must be weaponlesse.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: With all our harts.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Here: take these weapons in,
Stand of a little pray, so, so, tis well:
Ile shew you here a man that was sometimes,
A very graue and wealthy Cittizen,
Has serud a prentiship to this misfortune,
Bin here seuen yeares, and dwelt in Bergamo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How fell he from his wits?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: By losse at Sea:
Ile stand aside, question him you alone,
For if he spy me, heele not speake a word,
Vnlesse hees throughly vext. Discouers an old man, wrapt in a Net.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Alas poore soule.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A very old man.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: God speed father.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.l: God speed the plough: thou shalt not speed me.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: We see you old man, for all you daunce in a net.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.l: True, but thou wilt daunce in a halter, & I shal not see thee.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O, doe not vex him pray.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Are you a Fisherman father?

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.l: No, i'me neither fish nor flesh.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: What do you with that net then?

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p:
Doest not see foole! theres a fresh Salmon in't: if you step one foot furder, youle be ouer shoes, for you see ime
ouer head & ear in the salt-water: & if you fal into this whirl-poole where I am, y'are drownd: y'are a drownd rat.— I am fishing here for fiue ships, but I cannot haue a good draught, for my net breakes still, and breakes, but Ile breake some of your necks & I catch you in my clutches. Stay, stay, stay, stay— where's the wind, wheres the wind, wheres the winde: wheres the winde: out you guls, you goose-caps, you gudgeon eaters! do you looke for the wind in the heauens? ha ha ha ha, no no, looke there, looke there, looke there, the winde is alwayes at that doore: hearke how it blowes, pooff pooff, pooff.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Do you laugh at Gods creatures? do you mock old age you roagues? is this gray beard and head counterfet, that you cry ha ha ha?— Sirra, art not thou my eldest sonne?

sp.speaker: Pior.
sp.p: Yes indeed father.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Then th'art a foole, for my eldest sonne had a polt foote, crooked legs, a vergis face, & a peare-coullourd beard; I made him a scholler, and he made himselfe a foole.— Sirra! thou there? hould out thy hand.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: My hand, wel, here tis.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Looke, looke, looke, looke: has he not long nailes, and short haire?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Yes monstrous short haire, and abhominable long nailes.

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.p: Ten-peny naile's are they not?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Yes ten peny nailes.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Such nailes had my second boy: kneele downe thou varlet, and aske thy father blessing. Such nailes had my midlemost sonne and I made him a Promoter: & he scrapt, & scrapt, & scrapt, till he got the diuell and all: but he scrapt thus and thus, & thus, and it went vnder his legs, till at length a company of Kites taking him for carion, swept vp all, all, all all, all, all, all.— If you loue your liues, looke to your selues, see, see, see, see, the Turkes gallies are fighting with my ships, Bownce goes the guns.— oooh! cry the men: romble romble goe the waters— Alas! there! tis sunke— tis sunck: I am vndon, I am vndon, you are the dambd Pirates haue vndone me,— you are byth Lord, you are, you are, stop em, you are.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Why how now Syrra, must I fall to tame you?

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Tame me? no: ile be madder than a roasted Cat: see, see, I am burnt with gunpowder, these are our close fights.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Ile whip you, if you grow vnruly thus.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Whip me? out you toad:— whip me? what iustice is this, to whip me because Ime a begger?— Alas? I am a poore man: a very poore man: I am starud, and haue had no meate by this light, euer since the great floud, I am a poore man.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Well, well; be quiet and you shall haue meate.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: I, I, pray do, for looke you, here be my guts: these are my ribs,— you may looke through my ribs,— see how my guts come out— these are my red guttes, my very guts, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.p: Take him in there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: A very pitious sight.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Father I see you haue a busie charge.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: They must be vsde like children, pleasd with toyes,
And anon whipt for their vnrulinesse:
Ile shew you now a paire quite different
From him thats gon; he was all words: and these
Vnlesse you vrge em, seldome spend their speech,
But saue their tongues la— you this hithermost
Fell from the happy quietnesse of mind,
About a maiden that he loude, and dyed:
He followed her to church, being full of teares,
And as her body went into the ground,
He fell starke mad. That is a maryed man,
Was iealous of a faire, but (as some say)
A very vertuous wife, and that spoild him.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: All these are whoremongers & lay with my wife: whore, whore, whore, whore, whore.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Obserue him.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p:
Gaffer shoomaker, you puld on my wiues pumps, and then crept into her pantofles: lye there, lye there,— this was her Tailer,- you cut out her loose-bodied gowne, and put in a yard more then I allowed her, lye there by the shomaker: ô, maister Doctor! are you here: you gaue me a purgation, and then crept into my wiues chamber, to feele her pulses, and you said, and she sayd, and her mayd said, that they went pit a pat-pit a pat-pit a pat,- Doctor Ile put you anon into my wiues vrinall:- heigh, come a loft Iack? this was her school-maister, and taught her to play vpon the Virginals, and still his Iacks leapt vp, vp: you prickt her out nothing but bawdy
lessons, but Ile prick you all,- Fidler-Doctor-Tayler-Shoomaker,- Shoomaker-Fidler-Doctor-Tayler-so! lye with my wife agen now.

sp.speaker: Castr.
sp.p: See how he notes the other now he feedes.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Giue me some porridge.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Ile giue thee none.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Giue me some porridge.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Ile not giue thee a bit,

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Giue me that flap-dragon.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Ile not giue thee a spoonefull: thou liest, its no Dragon tis a Parrat, that I bought for my sweete heart, and ile keepe it.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Heres an Almond for Parrat.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Hang thy selfe.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Heres a roape for Parrat.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Eate it, for ile eate this.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Ile shoote at thee and thow't giue me none.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Wut thou?

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Ile run a tilt at thee and thow't giue me none.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Wut thou? doe and thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Bownce.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Ooh! I am slaine murder, —murder, murder, I am slaine, my braines are beaten out.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: How now you villaines, bring me whips: ile whip you

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: I am dead, I am slaine, ring out the bel, for I am dead,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: How will you do now sirra? you ha kild him.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Ile answer't at Sessions: he was eating of Almond Butter, and I longd for't: the child had neuer bin deliuered out of my belly, if I had not kild him Ile answer't at sessions, so my wife may be burnt ith hand too.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Take em in both: bury him, for hees dead.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: I indeed, I am dead, put me I pray into a good pit hole.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Ile answer't at Sessions. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: How now huswife, whether gad you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A nutting forsooth: how doe you gaffer? how doe you gaffer? theres a French cursie for you too.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Tis Bellafronte.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Tis the puncke byth Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Father whats she I pray?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: As yet I know not,
She came but in this day, talkes little idlely
And therefore has the freedome of the house,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Doe not you know me? nor you? nor you, nor you?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: No indeede.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then you are an Asse, and you are an Asse, and you are an Asse, for I know you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Why, what are they? come: tell me, what are they?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The're fish-wiues: will you buy any gudgeons, gods santy yonder come Friers, I know them too, how doe you Frier?

div.stage: Enter Hipolito, Mathaeo, and Infaeliche disguisde in the Habets of Friers.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Nay, nay, away, you must not trouble Friers.
The duke is here speake nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay indeed you shall not goe: weele run at barlibreak first, and you shalbe in hell.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: My puncke turnd mad whore, as all her fellowes are?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Speake nothing, but steale hence, when you spie time.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Ile locke you vp if y'are vnruly fie

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: fie! mary so: they shall not goe indeed till I ha tolde em their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Good Father giue her leaue.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I pray, good father, and Ile giue you my blessing.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Wel then be briefe, but if you are thus vnruly,
Ile haue you lockt vp fast.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: come, to their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let me see 1.2.3. and 4. ile begin with the little Frier first, heres a fine hand indeed, I neuer saw Frier haue such a dainty hand: heres a hand for a Lady, heres your fortune,

lg.l: You loue a Frier better then a Nun,
Yet long youle loue no Frier, nor no Friers sonne.
Bow a little, the line of life is out, yet i'me afraid,
For all your holy, youle not die a maide, God giue you ioy.
Now to you Frier Tucke.

sp.speaker: Mat,
sp.p: God send me good lucke.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You loue one, and one loues you.
You are a false knaue, and shees a Iew,
Here is a Diall that false euer goes.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O your wit drops.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Troth so does your nose, nay lets shake hands with you too:
Pray open, heres a fine hand,
Ho Fryer ho, God be here,
So he had need: youle keepe good cheere,
Heres a free table, but a frozen breast,
For youle starue those that loue you best.
Yet you haue good fortune, for if I am no lyar,
Then you are no Frier, nor you, nor you no Frier discouers them
Haha haha.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Are holy habits cloakes for villanie?
Draw all your weapons.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: doe, draw all your weapons.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Where are your weapons, draw.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: The Frier has guld vs of em.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O rare tricke:
You ha learnt one mad point of Arithmaticke.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why swels your spleene so hie? against what bosome,
Would you your weapons draw? hers! tis your daughters:
Mine! tis your sonnes.

sp.speaker: Duk:
sp.l: Sonne?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sonne, by yonder Sunne.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You cannot shed blould here, but tis your owne,
To spill your owne bloud were damnation,
Lay smooth that wrinckled brow, and I will throw
My selfe beneath your feete,
Let it be rugged still and flinted o're,
What can come forth but sparkles, that will burne,
Your selfe and vs? Shees mine; my claymes most good,
Shees mine by marriage, tho shees yours by bloud.
I haue a hand deare Lord, deepe in this act,
For I foresaw this storme, yet willingly
Put fourth to meete it? Oft haue I seene a father
Washing the wounds of his deare sonne in teares,
A sonne to curse the sword that strucke his father,
Both slaine ith quarrell of your families,
Those scars are now tane off: And I beseech you,
To seale our pardon, all was to this end
To turne the ancient hates of your two houses
To fresh greene friendship, that your Loues might looke:
Like the springs forehead, comfortably sweete,
And your vext soules in peacefull vnion meete,
Their bloud will now be yours, yours will be theirs,
And happinesse shall crowne your siluer haires.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: You see my Lord theres now no remedy.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Beseech your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: You beseech faire, you haue me in place fit
To bridle me, rise Frier. you may be glad
You can make madmen tame, and tame men mad,
Since fate hath conquered, I must rest content,
To striue now would but ad new punishment:
I yeeld vnto your happinesse, be blest,
Our families shall henceforth breath in rest.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O happy change.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Yours now is my consent,
I throw vpon your ioyes my full consent.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Am not I a good girle, for finding the Frier in the wel? gods so you are a braue man: will not you buy me some Suger plums because I am so good a fortune teller.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Would thou hadst wit thou pretty soule to aske,
As I haue will to giue.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pretty soule, a prety soule is better than a prety body: do not you know my prety soule? I know you: Is not your name Mathaeo.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes lamb.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Baa, lamb! there you lie for I am mutton; looke fine man, he was mad for me once, and I was mad for him once, and he was madde for her once, and were you neuer mad? yes I warrant, I had a fine iewell once, a very fine iewell and that naughty man stoale it away from me, a very fine iewell.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: What iewell pretty maide.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Maide nay thats a lie, O twas a very rich iewell, calde
a Maidenhead, and had not you it leerer.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Out you mad Asse away.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Had he thy Maiden-head? he shall make thee amends, and marry thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Shall he? ô braue Arthur of Bradly then?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: And if he beare the minde of a Gentleman,
I know he will.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I thinke I rifled her of some such paltry Iewell.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Did you? then mary her, you see the wrong
Has led her spirits into a lunacie.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How, marry her my Lord? sfoot marry a mad-woman: let a man get the tamest wife he can come by, sheele be mad enough afterward, doe what he can.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Nay then, father Anselmo here shall do his best,
To bring her to her wits, and will you then?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I may choose.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Nay then law shall compell: I tell you sir,
So much her hard fate moues me: you should not breath ile mary her.
Vnder this ayre, vnlesse you marryed her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well then, when her wits stand in their right place,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I thanke your grace, Mathaeo thou art mine,
I am not mad, but put on this disguise,
Onely for you my Lord, for you can tell
Much wonder of me, but you are gon: farewell.
Mathaeo thou didst first turne my soule black,
Now make it white agen, I doe protest,
Ime pure as fire now, chaste as Cynthias brest.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I durst be sworne Mathaeo she's indeed.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Cony-catcht, guld, must I saile in your flie-boate,
Because I helpt to reare your maine-mast first:
Plague found you fort,- tis well.
The Cuckolds stampe goes currant in all Nations,
Some men haue hornes giuen them at their creations,
If I be one of those, why so: its better
To take a common wench, and make her good,
Than one that simpers and at first, will scarse
Be tempted forth ouer the threshold dore,
Yet in one sennight zounds, turnes arrant whore,
Come wench, thou shalt be mine, giue me thy gols,
Weele talke of legges hereafter: see my Lord,
God giue vs ioy.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: God giue you ioy.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Come mistris we are in Bedlam now, mas and see, we come in pudding-time, for heres the Duke.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: My husband good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Haue I thy husband?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Its Candido my Lord, he's here among the lunaticks: father Anselmo, pray fetch him forth: this mad woman is his wife, and tho shee were not with child, yet did she long most spitefully to haue her husband mad, and because shee would be sure, he should turne Iew, she placde him here in Bethlem, yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come hither Signior— Are you mad.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: You are not mad.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why I know that.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then may you know, I am not mad, that know
You are not mad, and that you are the duke:
None is mad here but one— How do you wife:
What do you long for now?— pardon my Lord,
Shee had lost her childes nose els: I did cut out
Penniworths of Lawne, the Lawne was yet mine owne:
A carpet was yet my gowne, yet twas mine owne,
I wore my mans coate. yet the cloath mine owne,
Had a crackt crowne the crowne was yet mine owne,
She sayes for this Ime mad, were her words true,
I should be mad indeed— ô foolish skill,
Is patience madnesse? Ile be a mad-man still.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Forgiue me, and ile vex your spirit no more.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Come, come, weele haue you friends, ioyne hearts, ioyne hands.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: See my Lord, we are euen,
Nay rise, for ill-deeds kneele vnto none but heauen.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Signior, me thinkes, patience has laid on you
Such heauy waight, that you should loath it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Loath it.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: For he whose brest is tender bloud so coole,
That no wrongs heate it, is a patient foole,
What comfort do you finde in being so calme.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: That which greene wounds receiue from soueraigne balme,
Patience my Lord; why tis the soule of peace:
Of all the vertues tis neerst kin to heauen.
It makes men looke like Gods; the best of men
That ere wore earth about him, was a sufferer,
A soft, meeke, patient, humble, tranquill spirit,
The first true Gentleman that euer breathd;
The stock of Patience then cannot be poore,
All it desires, it has; what Monarch more?
It is the greatest enemy to law
That can be, for it doth embrace all wrongs,
And so chaines vp, lawyers and womens tongues.
Tis the perpetuall prisoners liberty:
His walkes and Orchards: 'tis the bond-slaues freedome,
And makes him seeme prowd of each yron chaine.
As tho he wore it more for state then paine:
It is the beggers Musick, and thus sings,
Although their bodies beg, their soules are kings:
O my dread liege! It is the sap of blisse,
Reares vs aloft; makes men and Angels kisse,
And (last of all) to end a houshould strife,
It is the hunny gainst a waspish wife.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou giu'st it liuely coulours: who dare say
he's mad, whose words march in so good aray?
Twere sinne all women should such husbands haue.
For euery man must then be his wiues slaue.
Come therefore you shall teach our court to shine,
So calme a spirit is worth a golden Mine,
Wiues (with meeke husbands) that to vex them long,
In Bedlam must they dwell, els dwell they wrong.
